J .B. wrote:

  >I write unit tests for the low level objects, and also for the higher
level
  >aggregating objects that use them.  [...]

  So you have two main test suites.

  1. Object-level tests.
  2. Integration tests.

  This necessarily means that you do not have the benefit of "one defect,
one failure", since likely you always have "one defect, at least two
failures".

No, I have a complex hierarchy.

  >Since
  >I can't control the order of execution (it is likely package alphabetical
  >or
  >something), I can't tell what is the lowest level test. I'd like to
reduce
  >the effort invested here.

  This is a myth. You *can* control the order of execution of test and of
test suites; you simply have to maintain suites.

As  I said above, I know I *probably* could do it with suites ... BUT. As I
refactor, as code grows, the suites (being separate from the tests) are .
but that seems a level of manual effort/management that is counter
productive -- and hence counter testing. IMHO anything that can be better
done by a computer ought be done by a computer.

Say I have an object X that aggregates Y and Z I want X to depend upon Y
tests and Z tests. What suite would I create? Also, say I have A that
aggregate B and C -- with finally an object aggregating X and A. What if A
started using X? Trying to manage suites to represent this hierarchy seems
nightmarish.

I would like to be able to set X to depend upon Y/Z (almost a "dynamic
suite") and set A on Y and Z. Then, if A started using X I'd just have to
set A to depend upon X to get the desire hierarchy. [Doing this in the
original class might be nicer still, but I've not yet thought how to tie
tests with classes so tightly (and be efficient).]

Is what I am discussing unreasonable? It seems an easy interface for users,
and something that junit could manage behind the scenes.

[Gosh, if the Eclipse junit wizard did this for me via class introspection,
that'd be a beautiful thing...]

  >P.S. The Eclipse junit plugin that search projects to find all tests,
find
  >tests in dependant project, but doesn't run them "in the CWD of that
  >project" (which matters for some tests).

  It shouldn't. It is best to write your tests so that it doesn't. Or your
production code; whichever. Pass the desired working directory into the
tests as a JVM parameter or something.


I might agree with you, but I am testing ant tasks -- that process XML
files -- and it seems wholly reasonable that they read them from a file.
Since I am subclassing from the test utility that ant provides for this, I
have to use the file mechanism they provide. Also, since I am not launching
the junit (Eclipse is) I don't have the JVM control you state -- especially
when it is choosing to run tests from multiple projects.

I guess I'll file a bug report/enhancement request and see what luck I get.

regards,

Adam
